titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Herbert Scarf papers, 1951-2015 RL.11619
titlestmt.author: Jon Cogliano

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-06 09:13:54 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

physdesc.extent: 3 floppy disks with 11 files (one disk unreadable)

did.abstract: Herbert Scarf (1930-2015) was an economist and mathematician, and worked as a professor of economics at Yale University and the Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics. This collection consists of his correspondence, research, and writings, as well as his collaborations and professional affiliations across the fields of economics, mathematics, and operations research. Includes a small group of electronic files; computations and other technical data contained in these files may be available in the form of printouts in the collection's research files. Acquired as part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into these series: Correspondence (including name files); Writings; Research and Notes; Academia; and Personal.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Herbert Eli Scarf (1930-2015) was an American economist and mathematician born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He died at 85 on November 15, 2015 in Sag Harbor, New York. He earned his undergraduate degree (A.B. Mathematics) at Temple University in 1951 and completed his Ph.D. in Mathematics at Princeton University in 1954. From 1954 to 1957 Scarf worked in the Mathematics and Economics Departments and the RAND Corporation before joining Stanford University as an Assistant Professor of Statistics in 1957. In 1963 Scarf joined the Economics Department at Yale University and the Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics. Scarf remained at Yale for the remainder of his career as the Stanley Resor Professor of Economics (1970-1978) and the Sterling Professor of Economics (1979-2015). Scarf was awarded the Frederick W. Lanchester Prize (1973) and the John von Neumann Theory Prize (1983) by the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences, and served as President of the Econometric Society in 1983.

A primary focus of Scarf's research was the computation of economic equilibrium and fixed points, which serves as the basis for applied general equilibrium models. Scarf also made significant contributions to understanding the stability of general equilibrium, the core of many-person games and its relation to general equilibrium, integer programming, and economic production with indivisibilities. Much of Scarf's work is a precursor to modern computational and simulation approaches to economics. His wife, Maggie Scarf, is the author of several award-winning books on family relationships and marriage.

Director, Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics
Stanley Resor Professor of Economics, Yale University
Director, Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Herbert Scarf Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Herbert Scarf papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Electronic media description added by Paula Jeannet, September 2020
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2017-0012

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Herbert Scarf Papers document his career as an economist and mathematician. The collection provides an overview of his professional activities, particularly his research and writings on the computation of economic equilibrium and fixed points, stability of general equilibrium, the core of many-person games and its relation to general equilibrium, integer programming, and problems of production with indivisibilities. Much of Scarf's work serves as the basis for applied general equilibrium models, and as a precursor to modern computational and simulation approaches to economics.

The collection also documents Scarf's collaboration and communications with prominent economists and mathematicians such as Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Ralph Gomory, Terje Hansen, Werner Hildenbrand, Tjalling Koopmans, Harold Kuhn, Lloyd Shapley, John Shoven, Martin Shubik, John Whalley, and many others.

Along with his own scholarship and writings, the collection documents Scarf's leadership roles in the American Economic Association, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Econometric Society, and other organizations; and his departmental roles, committee work, and teaching contributions in the economics, operations research, and applied mathematics programs at Yale University.

Includes a small group of electronic files originally on floppy disks created in the 1980s, which have been migrated to a library server. Computations and other technical data contained in these files may be available in the form of printouts in the collection's research files.
Acquired as part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Scarf's name files on various individuals and general correspondence. Scarf maintained correspondence files for particular individuals of note and his Ph.D. advisees (including copies of dissertations), while collecting other correspondence in General Correspondence folders. This series also contains Scarf's correspondence with various publishers and academic journals. Correspondents of note include Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Duncan Foley, Ralph Gomory, Werner Hildenbrand, Tim Kehoe, Tjalling Koopmans, Harold Kuhn, Michael Mandler, Rolf Mantel, Joan Robinson, John Shoven, Martin Shubik, and John Whalley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Scarf's notes and correspondence for research projects, and a portion of his collection of academic writings by others. Research notes include files on Scarf's work on general equilibrium theory, the computation of economic equilibrium and fixed points, his collaboration with Terje Hansen, and methods of integer programming to compute economic equilibrium under certain conditions. Of note is a Rolodex with Scarf's bibliographic citations listing articles he referenced or read as part of his research.
The Research subseries includes three disks containing electronic files related to Scarf's computational projects. One disk was unreadable.

accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains documents in various formats related to Scarf's research projects, including his work with Terje Hansen, the core and general equilibrium, and computation of economic equilibrium and fixed points.

Includes a small group of electronic files originally on floppy disks created in the 1980s, which have been migrated to a library server; computations and other technical data contained in these files may be available in the form of printouts in the collection's research files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes select articles and book chapters used in Scarf's research. Unindexed files are not indexed by topic; the other topics -- Fixed points, General, and Integer were assigned by Scarf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains copies, reprints, drafts, notes, and other documents associated with Scarf's published works. These include: reprints and copies of published journal articles and book chapters; contributions to festschrift volumes; and documents from his referee activity for academic journals and publishers.
